The National Academy of
Sciences was established in 1863,
under a Congressional charter
signed by President Lincoln, as a
private, nonprofit organization
of scientists to advance science
and advise the government on
scientific and technical matters.

Director Of Admissions Asserts
No Religious, Racial Prejudice
"We have no fixed percentage
for the admission of different denominations of students," said
Director of Admissions William
F. Logan when questioned by the
News-Letter this week.
"The admissions office has no
objections to admitting Negroes
or people of any religious belief
. . . in fact we try to get as
many Negro students as we can,"
he stated.

"We are working closely with

and Fund for Negro Students
and have made two tuition

Hopkins,Museum Of Art
To Present Symposium
The Fine Arts Department of
the Johns Hopkins University, in
collaboration with the Baltimore
Museum of Art, will inaugurate
a symposium on "The Spirit of
the Eighteenth Century in Art,
Literature and Music" this evening at 8:30 in the Museum auditorium.
The symposium will span the
three-day weekend and present
lectures, illustrated talks, refreshments and a concert. No
admission tickets are required
and anyone is welcome.
Dr. Maurice Mandelbaum, Professor of Philosophy at Johns
Hopkins, will give an introductory talk this evening at 8:30
which will be followed by an
illustrated lecture on Fantasy
Architecture by Bates Lowry, Assistant Professor of Art at the
Institute of Fine Arts, New York
University.

Tomorrow at 3 p.m. Dr. George
Boas, Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Johns Hopkins University will lecture on Reynolds
as an Arbiter of Taste. Refreshments will follow in the auditorium foyer.
Dominant Designs in Eighteenth Century Literature will
be the subject of a lecture at
5 p.m. tomorrow by Dr. Earl
Wasserman, Professor of English Literature at Johns Hopkins.
On Sunday at 5 p.m. Dr. Donald J. Grout, Professor of Music
at Cornell University, will give
a lecture on The Irrational in
Eightenth Century Music. At
8:30 p.m. a Concert of Eighteenth Century Music will be
presented by a musical group
conducted by Eliot Galkin, Assistant Professor of Music at
Goucher College.

The prospects for next year's
Freshman Class are "indefinite"
as yet, according to Logan, who
noted that "a class of 400 is
what we always shoot for, but
the figures as they stand now
be meaningless since
would
they'll change so much."
As for the departmental makeup of the incoming class, Logan
stated: "Our goal is always to
get a certain number of freshmen in each of the three basic
fields. We don't always get them.
Last year, there was an-improvement in the number of humanities students."
This year the admissions office
has inaugurated a plan to obtain better roommate assignments in the dormitories for the
incoming frosh. A questionnaire
prepared by associate admissions
director Robert Bilgrave has been
circulated to be answered by all
freshmen applying for dorm
occupancy.
The questionnaire asks questions concerning smoking habits,
preferred sleeping hours, study
time, fraternity aspirations, etc.
The questionnaire "will be used
to help the dormitory committee
pair off roommates as intelligently as possible."

They were questioned pout the

of the $1 bill. They walked off

Hoods Provoke Fight
The Wilson group stayed about
100 yards away and sent someone to call the police. After
about ten minutes the hoods got
brave and approached the Hopkins students. The three each
clutched beer bottles as if they
intended to use them as weapons.
They started to insult and abuse
the nine and dared them to fight.
The Wilson men wished to avoid
a fight and waited quietly in hope
that the police would soon arrive.
After 20 minutes the police
failed to show up and the Hopkins students decided to leave.
They had obtained the license
plate number of the hoods' car
and were confident that they
could be traced with this information. During the twenty
minutes of waiting the hoodlums had been quite eager, for
some unknown reason, to get
back the wooden cane which Stan
Weiss was holding. When the

group started to leave they became very angry and started
screaming for the cane. The Wilson group continued on. Before

Humphrey Gives Views
On U. S. Foreign Policy
Senator Hubert Humphrey,
speaking as a guest lecturer in
a class at Hopkins last Friday,
gave his opinions on foreign
policy, economic aid, and the
work of the United Nations.
Senator Humphrey stated that
the moving forces in history are
expressed today in terms of
scientific discovery and mutual
assistance programs.

SEN. HUBERT HUMPHREY

A most notable example of the
latter, he said, was President
Truman's Inaugural Address in
which he outlined the Foul-Point program.
Will Be Important Later
"The importance of this will
be shown later on," said Senator Humphreys, "for other nations are going to determine our
future. The balance of power is
in Asia, Latin America, and
Africa. These areas are also becoming increasingly important
in terms of population, natural
resources, and future markets."
Program Has Wrong Name
The senator stated, however,
that the United States is not
using the economic aid program
in the best way. "The first thing
wrong with it is the name we
give it. We call it 'Defense Support.' This makes it much easier
to raise money for it at home,
but it reduces the effectiveness
of the program abroad."
"Another thing wrong," said
Senator Humphrey, "is the fact

Homecoming
Homecoming is for the alumnus a time during which
medals are given, friendships renewed and memories rekindled. But most important it is a time when the alumnus
can at first hand observe the changes, the progress, the
overall improvement of his alma mater.
This is especially true at Johns Hopkins, a university
dedicated to constant improvement and progress in all
fields of knowledge and research. To provide the alumnus
with an opportunity to come in close contact with her
development and reawaken him to the responsibility he
will always have to aid her, financially as well as via public
relations, an Alumni Homecoming becomes the most necessary and worthwhile event possible.
Therefore may the alumnus return with a feeling of
gratitude to his alma mater and a sense of pride in her
accomplishments. Johns Hopkins is a great university,
one as proud of her alumni as they are of her, and one
who needs their support as much as they once needed hers.
A
We heartily welcome the alumni and only regret that
there will be so little socializing between them and the
undergraduates, an unfortunate fact that if remedied
would, we are sure, provide a more satisfying Homecoming
not only for the alumnus but for the student as well.

That students and their guests maintain good behavior at Sunday's Jazz Concert is imperative for the
continuation of such events at Hopkins. Whether we like
it or not, a displeased administration is the force that
can end this annual event, and almost did this year because of past conduct. If the students enjoy and want
to continue these concerts in future, their own behavior
will prove the deciding factor.

It goes without saying that students planning raids
at Maryland University next week will be taking their own
futures in their hands. Often condoned in the past, such
"parties" are now only irritating and can be harmful
to persons as well as property. The energies that come
of such spirit are better put to warding off raids on our
own campus, if they come, and to venting vocal team support at the game itself.
In view of the stringent penalties connected with
raids on other campuses, we strongly urge anyone planning
such a foray to think twice beforehand. Is the emblazoning of one statue worth the threat of a trial and its ccnsequences?

ADVENTURES IN SOCIAL SCIENCE: NO. 3
Today,ranging again into the fascinating world of social science,
let us take up the subject of anthropology—the study of man
and his origins.
The origin of man was indeed a puzzle until the Frenchman,
Jean-Louis Sigafoos, discovered the skull and shinbone of
Pithecanthropus Erectus in Java in 1891. What Sigafoos was
doing in Java is, incidentally, quite an odd little story. Sigafoos
was a Parisian born and bred. By day one could always find
him at a sidewalk cafe, sipping barley water and ogling the
girls; each night he went to a fashjonable casino where he
gambled heavily at roulette and go-fish; in between times he
worked on his stamp collection, which was one of the largest
in Paris.

4e4eVitrite/7.
4.

Well sir, one summer Sigafoos lost his entire fortune gambling
at the casino. He was seriously contemplating suicide when,
quite unexpectedly, a letter arrived from one Lotus Petal
McGinnis, a Javanese girl and an avid stamp collector, with
Whom Sigafoos had been corresponding from time to time
through the international stamp collectors journal. Until now
the nature of their correspondence, though friendly, had been
strictly philatelic, but in this new letter Lotus Petal declared
that although she had never laid eyek on Sigafoos, she loved
him and wanted to marry him. She said she was eighteen years
old, beautiful and docile, and her father, the richest man in the
tribe, had agreed to give half his fortune to the husband of her
choice. Sigafoos, penniless and desperate, immediately booked
passage for Java.
The first sight of his prospective bride failed to delight Sigafoos. She was, as she said, beautiful —but only by local standards. Sigafoos had serious doubts that her pointed scarlet teeth
and the chicken bones banging from her ears would be considered chic along the Champs Elysees.
But sobering as was the sight of Lotus Petal, Sigafoos had
an even greater disappointment coining when he met her father.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 8, 1959

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

Hopkins To Meet Terrors Morrill Paces Squad
In Mediocre Contest
In Final Week Of Season
Opening the last week of play
of the current baseball season,
the Western Maryland Green
Terrors visit Homewood Field
tomorrow at 12 noon for a
Mason-Dixon Conference tilt.
In the Jays' previous match
with Western Maryland at Westminster ten days ago, the Terrors hung on to take an 18-13
decision over Hopkins.
Dickinson College will be hosted by the Blue Jays here next
Tuesday in the final diamond
scrap of the year. Hopkins
whipped Dickinson at Carlisle
last season by a score of 3-2.
Coach Ross Sachs will be ready
to throw any • and all of his
moundsmen in this final battle,
in an attempt. to end the year
on a winning note.
Catholic U. Tops Jays
The varsity diamond crew saw
its record sink to 3-9 last Tuesday as the Jays went down, 6-3,
to Catholic University.

Hopkins Linksmen
Vie In Tourneys
As Season Ends
The Hopkins golf team will
participate in the thirteenth annual Mason-Dixon conference
tournament to be held on Tuesday, May 12, at Mount Pleasant
Golf Club in Baltimore.
The tournament will be a 36hole medal play test, 18 holes in
the morning, starting at 8:30
a.m., with the 18-hole afternoon
round at 1:30 or there-about.
The 1958 tourney was won by
the University of Baltimore, with
Bridegwater, and Western Maryland placing second and third.
The Jays, who took the dual meet
title in 1958 did not place in the
top three.
The day before the M-D tourney, Monday, May 11, the Hopkins links crew travels to Newark, Delaware, to participate in
the Middle Atlantic tourney.

The Cardinals scored singletons in the third and eighth and
twice in the fourth and fifth to
pile up their six run, eleven hit
attack. The Homewood club
scored once in each of the
fourth, fifth, and sixth innings
while piling up five hits. Mike
Hodge was tagged with the Jay
defeat.
Ey Holds Sho'men
Last Saturday, the Jays were
defeated by Washington College
by a score of 3-1. Larry Ey, ace
of the Homewood mound staff,
hurled a nifty eight hitter
against the Sho'men, but went
down to his second loss against
three victories. Ey had previously against Swarthmore turned
in the first Jay shutout in years.
The Jays collected six hits and
had men on base in six innings,
but could only score once,
stranding eight runners. Jack
Kotowski, with a single and a
double, and Bill Karpovicz, with
a single and a triple, led the
Hopkins batters. Leading Washington was catcher Bragg, who
scored all three runs, and collected a home run in the
process.
Karpowicz singled in the Hopkins first, but was left stranded.
Bragg led off the Sho'men first
with a walk, and stole second on
the next pitch. He scored on a
Blue-Jay error on the next play.
Karpowicz Drives in Run
The Jays went down in 1-2-3
fashion in the second and third
innings. Washington wasted a
single in the second, but picked
a second run on Bragg's homer
in the third.
In the Hopkins fourth, Kotowski led off with a single, and
scored on a booming triple by
Karpowicz, but the Jay center
fielder was left stranded three

quarters of the way around, as
the next three batters went out.
Hopkins went out in order in
the fifth, while Washington
wasted a fourth inning double
and two fifth inning singles.
The Jays threatened in the
sixth, as Kotowski doubled and
Al Figinski walked, but, once
again, they died on base. Third
sacker Mary Jones walked to
open the seventh, was sacrificed
to second, and was left stranded.
The Sho'men were put down in
order in the sixth, but a single,
a stolen base, and another hit
scored Bragg again in the
seventh.
Closest Hopkins Rally
The eighth inning saw the
Jays put on their closest rally
of the day. Sol DeSwaan
singled, and Bill Karpowicz
walked with one out. Co-captain
Figinski took first on a fielder's
choice as Karpowicz was thrown
out, and DeSwaan took third.
Second sacker Danny Zelman
then sent out a hot smash in the
hole between second and third.
Washington
Somehow, the
shortstop came up with the ball,
and whipped a throw in the direction of second base. Figinski
slid in, beating the throw to
second, and then watched the
umpire call him out, as the
throw arrived a second later.
This bad call cost the Jays at
least one run and perhaps the
opportunity of tying the game.
Washington went down in
order under Ey's pitching in the
eighth, but Hopkins was not fin
ished yet. With two down in
the ninth, pinch hitter Jim
Clark clipped a single to left,
putting the tying run at the
plate. But pinch runner Dick
Koslowski was left stranded as
Ey struck out to end the game.

(Continued from Page 7)
The Hopkins varsity stickmen
played a lacklustre, if not mediocre, game in defeating Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 19-7,
last week at Troy, N. Y.
Though handling an extremely
weak squad with ease, the Jays
came through with a poor team
effort, though some individual
performances were outstanding.
The let-down is understandable
in view of the extreme effort
that was demanded of the Jays
to defeat Rutgers the previous
week.
The men from Homewood
opened the contest with four
straight goals and closed with a
five goal splurge to take their
twenty-third straight victory.
Billy Morrill opened the scoring at 1:44 of the first period.
He fed Berndt twice and Bernstein once to push the Jays in
front by 4-0 with eight minutes
gone.
The second half followed much
the same pattern, with the men
in Blue scoring five times in each
period as they continued to
break through the Rensselaer
defense.
Harry Weitzel put
across the final tally with nine
seconds of play remaining in
the contest.
Morrill led the scoring, as
usual, with five tallies, bringing
his seven-game total to 37, an
average of over five goals a contest. He also contributed five
assists in the contest. (Morrill's
often-neglected proficiency at
feeding has netted the Jay attackmen 18 goals so far this
season, second on the club only

to Mickey Webster's 40.)
Webster turned in one of his
best all-round scoring perforra•
ances, netting four goals (12 for
the year) in addition to WI

assists.

Library Clamps Down
On Entry Into Stacks
Recent enforcement by the library staff of rules prohibiting
undergraduates from entry into
stacks adjacent to the Main
Reading Room was described as
"just trying to have a little
tighter control by reaffirming a

Lecture
Frank H. Westheimer, Professor of Chemistry at Harvard University, will deliver
the Glidden Company Lectures in Chemistry at Hopkins, Thursday and Friday,
May 7 and 8.
The lectures will he given
in Shriver Hall at 8:30 p.m.
lnd will be open to the public
without charge.
Professor Westheimer, a
native of Baltimore, was educated at Darthmouth and
Harvard.

NORTHWAY TAILORS

basic policy" by Assistant Librarian John Haas.
M. Haas pointed out that the
rule of closed stacks was not in
any way new, but that is just
being more tightly enforced now.
Graduate students were reporting thefts of books from their
desks in the stacks, he explained.
"We didn't know who was doing it, but we decided this was
the way to stop it."
Books had also been reported
missing from the shelves in the
stacks in larger than usual proportions. Enforcement of closed
stack rules, it is hoped, will combat this loss as well.

Hopkins,Museum Of Art
To Present Symposium
The Fine Arts Department of
the Johns Hopkins University, in
collaboration with the Baltimore
Museum of Art, will inaugurate
a symposium on "The Spirit of
the Eighteenth Century in Art,
Literature and Music" this evening at 8:30 in the Museum auditorium.
The symposium will span the
three-day weekend and present
lectures, illustrated talks, refreshments and a concert. No
admission tickets are required
and anyone is welcome.
Dr. Maurice Mandelbaum, Professor of Philosophy at Johns
Hopkins, will give an introductory talk this evening at 8:30
which will be followed by an
illustrated lecture on Fantasy

Institute of Fine Arts, New York
University.

as an Arbiter of Taste. Refreshments will follow in the auditorium foyer.

Wasserman, Professor of English Literature at Johns Hopkins.

at Cornell University, will give
a lecture on The Irrational in
Eightenth Century Music. At

the moving forces in history are
expressed today in terms of
scientific discovery and mutual
assistance programs.

resources, and future markets."

of the program abroad."

Homecoming
Homecoming is for the alumnus a time during which
medals are given, friendships renewed and memories rekindled. But most important it is a time when the alumnus
can at first hand observe the changes, the progress, the
overall improvement of his alma mater.
This is especially true at Johns Hopkins, a university
dedicated to constant improvement and progress in all
fields of knowledge and research. To provide the alumnus
with an opportunity to come in close contact with her
development and reawaken him to the responsibility he
will always have to aid her, financially as well as via public
relations, an Alumni Homecoming becomes the most necessary and worthwhile event possible.
Therefore may the alumnus return with a feeling of
gratitude to his alma mater and a sense of pride in her
accomplishments. Johns Hopkins is a great university,
one as proud of her alumni as they are of her, and one
who needs their support as much as they once needed hers.
A
We heartily welcome the alumni and only regret that
there will be so little socializing between them and the
undergraduates, an unfortunate fact that if remedied
would, we are sure, provide a more satisfying Homecoming
not only for the alumnus but for the student as well.

ADVENTURES IN SOCIAL SCIENCE: NO. 3
Today,ranging again into the fascinating world of social science,
let us take up the subject of anthropology—the study of man
and his origins.
The origin of man was indeed a puzzle until the Frenchman,
Jean-Louis Sigafoos, discovered the skull and shinbone of
Pithecanthropus Erectus in Java in 1891. What Sigafoos was
doing in Java is, incidentally, quite an odd little story. Sigafoos
was a Parisian born and bred. By day one could always find
him at a sidewalk cafe, sipping barley water and ogling the
girls; each night he went to a fashjonable casino where he
gambled heavily at roulette and go-fish; in between times he
worked on his stamp collection, which was one of the largest
in Paris.

4e4eVitrite/7.
4.

Well sir, one summer Sigafoos lost his entire fortune gambling
at the casino. He was seriously contemplating suicide when,
quite unexpectedly, a letter arrived from one Lotus Petal
McGinnis, a Javanese girl and an avid stamp collector, with
Whom Sigafoos had been corresponding from time to time
through the international stamp collectors journal. Until now
the nature of their correspondence, though friendly, had been
strictly philatelic, but in this new letter Lotus Petal declared
that although she had never laid eyek on Sigafoos, she loved
him and wanted to marry him. She said she was eighteen years
old, beautiful and docile, and her father, the richest man in the
tribe, had agreed to give half his fortune to the husband of her
choice. Sigafoos, penniless and desperate, immediately booked
passage for Java.
The first sight of his prospective bride failed to delight Sigafoos. She was, as she said, beautiful —but only by local standards. Sigafoos had serious doubts that her pointed scarlet teeth
and the chicken bones banging from her ears would be considered chic along the Champs Elysees.
But sobering as was the sight of Lotus Petal, Sigafoos had
an even greater disappointment coining when he met her father.

Registrar Denies Fault
Of June Week Conflict
The conflict between the end
of final examinations and the
beginning of June Week will remain "unchanged" according to
all parties concerned, the NewsLetter learned Tuesday.
The overlap caused by the occurrence of the Sports Dance
on the evening of June 1 and
the scheduling of many math
exams for the morning of June 2
resulted because "no one asked
me," stated Registrar Irene M.
Davis who points out that "final
exams have been running until
Tuesday for a long time."
When asked, Cotillion Board
President Rich DeVed asserted
that "this is not the fault of
the Cotillion Board, since June
Week is run by the chairmen
themselves." He added that Cotillion Board aid "is available
whenever they want to use it,"
but that "we weren't consulted."
June
Week
co-chairman
Charles Beinkampen stated that
"we followed the Cotillion Board
calendar which listed June 1 as
the final day of exams."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 8, 1959

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

Hopkins To Meet Terrors Morrill Paces Squad
In Mediocre Contest
In Final Week Of Season
Opening the last week of play
of the current baseball season,
the Western Maryland Green
Terrors visit Homewood Field
tomorrow at 12 noon for a
Mason-Dixon Conference tilt.
In the Jays' previous match
with Western Maryland at Westminster ten days ago, the Terrors hung on to take an 18-13
decision over Hopkins.
Dickinson College will be hosted by the Blue Jays here next
Tuesday in the final diamond
scrap of the year. Hopkins
whipped Dickinson at Carlisle
last season by a score of 3-2.
Coach Ross Sachs will be ready
to throw any • and all of his
moundsmen in this final battle,
in an attempt. to end the year
on a winning note.
Catholic U. Tops Jays
The varsity diamond crew saw
its record sink to 3-9 last Tuesday as the Jays went down, 6-3,
to Catholic University.

Hopkins Linksmen
Vie In Tourneys
As Season Ends
The Hopkins golf team will
participate in the thirteenth annual Mason-Dixon conference
tournament to be held on Tuesday, May 12, at Mount Pleasant
Golf Club in Baltimore.
The tournament will be a 36hole medal play test, 18 holes in
the morning, starting at 8:30
a.m., with the 18-hole afternoon
round at 1:30 or there-about.
The 1958 tourney was won by
the University of Baltimore, with
Bridegwater, and Western Maryland placing second and third.
The Jays, who took the dual meet
title in 1958 did not place in the
top three.
The day before the M-D tourney, Monday, May 11, the Hopkins links crew travels to Newark, Delaware, to participate in
the Middle Atlantic tourney.

The Cardinals scored singletons in the third and eighth and
twice in the fourth and fifth to
pile up their six run, eleven hit
attack. The Homewood club
scored once in each of the
fourth, fifth, and sixth innings
while piling up five hits. Mike
Hodge was tagged with the Jay
defeat.
Ey Holds Sho'men
Last Saturday, the Jays were
defeated by Washington College
by a score of 3-1. Larry Ey, ace
of the Homewood mound staff,
hurled a nifty eight hitter
against the Sho'men, but went
down to his second loss against
three victories. Ey had previously against Swarthmore turned
in the first Jay shutout in years.
The Jays collected six hits and
had men on base in six innings,
but could only score once,
stranding eight runners. Jack
Kotowski, with a single and a
double, and Bill Karpovicz, with
a single and a triple, led the
Hopkins batters. Leading Washington was catcher Bragg, who
scored all three runs, and collected a home run in the
process.
Karpowicz singled in the Hopkins first, but was left stranded.
Bragg led off the Sho'men first
with a walk, and stole second on
the next pitch. He scored on a
Blue-Jay error on the next play.
Karpowicz Drives in Run
The Jays went down in 1-2-3
fashion in the second and third
innings. Washington wasted a
single in the second, but picked
a second run on Bragg's homer
in the third.
In the Hopkins fourth, Kotowski led off with a single, and
scored on a booming triple by
Karpowicz, but the Jay center
fielder was left stranded three

quarters of the way around, as
the next three batters went out.
Hopkins went out in order in
the fifth, while Washington
wasted a fourth inning double
and two fifth inning singles.
The Jays threatened in the
sixth, as Kotowski doubled and
Al Figinski walked, but, once
again, they died on base. Third
sacker Mary Jones walked to
open the seventh, was sacrificed
to second, and was left stranded.
The Sho'men were put down in
order in the sixth, but a single,
a stolen base, and another hit
scored Bragg again in the
seventh.
Closest Hopkins Rally
The eighth inning saw the
Jays put on their closest rally
of the day. Sol DeSwaan
singled, and Bill Karpowicz
walked with one out. Co-captain
Figinski took first on a fielder's
choice as Karpowicz was thrown
out, and DeSwaan took third.
Second sacker Danny Zelman
then sent out a hot smash in the
hole between second and third.
Washington
Somehow, the
shortstop came up with the ball,
and whipped a throw in the direction of second base. Figinski
slid in, beating the throw to
second, and then watched the
umpire call him out, as the
throw arrived a second later.
This bad call cost the Jays at
least one run and perhaps the
opportunity of tying the game.
Washington went down in
order under Ey's pitching in the
eighth, but Hopkins was not fin
ished yet. With two down in
the ninth, pinch hitter Jim
Clark clipped a single to left,
putting the tying run at the
plate. But pinch runner Dick
Koslowski was left stranded as
Ey struck out to end the game.

The Hopkins varsity stickmen
played a lacklustre, if not mediocre, game in defeating Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 19-7,
last week at Troy, N. Y.
Though handling an extremely
weak squad with ease, the Jays
came through with a poor team
effort, though some individual
performances were outstanding.
The let-down is understandable
in view of the extreme effort
that was demanded of the Jays
to defeat Rutgers the previous
week.
The men from Homewood
opened the contest with four
straight goals and closed with a
five goal splurge to take their
twenty-third straight victory.
Billy Morrill opened the scoring at 1:44 of the first period.
He fed Berndt twice and Bernstein once to push the Jays in
front by 4-0 with eight minutes
gone.
The second half followed much
the same pattern, with the men
in Blue scoring five times in each
period as they continued to
break through the Rensselaer
defense.
Harry Weitzel put
across the final tally with nine
seconds of play remaining in
the contest.
Morrill led the scoring, as
usual, with five tallies, bringing
his seven-game total to 37, an
average of over five goals a contest. He also contributed five
assists in the contest. (Morrill's
often-neglected proficiency at
feeding has netted the Jay attackmen 18 goals so far this
season, second on the club only

to Mickey Webster's 40.)
Webster turned in one of his
best all-round scoring perforra•
ances, netting four goals (12 for
the year) in addition to WI

assists.

Library Clamps Down
On Entry Into Stacks
Recent enforcement by the library staff of rules prohibiting
undergraduates from entry into
stacks adjacent to the Main
Reading Room was described as
"just trying to have a little
tighter control by reaffirming a

Lecture
Frank H. Westheimer, Professor of Chemistry at Harvard University, will deliver
the Glidden Company Lectures in Chemistry at Hopkins, Thursday and Friday,
May 7 and 8.
The lectures will he given
in Shriver Hall at 8:30 p.m.
lnd will be open to the public
without charge.
Professor Westheimer, a
native of Baltimore, was educated at Darthmouth and
Harvard.

NORTHWAY TAILORS

basic policy" by Assistant Librarian John Haas.
M. Haas pointed out that the
rule of closed stacks was not in
any way new, but that is just
being more tightly enforced now.
Graduate students were reporting thefts of books from their
desks in the stacks, he explained.
"We didn't know who was doing it, but we decided this was
the way to stop it."
Books had also been reported
missing from the shelves in the
stacks in larger than usual proportions. Enforcement of closed
stack rules, it is hoped, will combat this loss as well.
